column1: The first dispute between Rome and Carthage was about their possession in the island of Sicily; and the war thus begun had lasted eight years
column2: when it was resolved to send an army to fight the Carthaginians on their own shores. The army and fleet were placed under the command of the two consuls
column3: Lucius Manlius and Marcus Attilius Regulus. On the way
column4: there was a great sea-fight with the Carthaginian fleet
column5: and this was the first naval battle that the Romans ever gained. It made the way to Africa free; but the soldiers
column6: who had never been so far from home before
column8: for they expected to meet not only human enemies
column14: to have a scorching sun overhead
column15: and a noisome marsh under their feet. However
column16: Regulus sternly put a stop to all murmurs
column17: by making it known that disaffection would be punished by death
column19: and set up a fortification at Clypea
column20: and plundered the whole country round.
